newsitem.title: USA: MGE spring wheat drifts to end mostly lower.
newsitem.headline: MGE spring wheat drifts to end mostly lower.

text.p: MGE spring wheat futures settled mostly lower in light volume on a general lack of buying, and traders said the market was focused on the Friday release of USDA's July crop report.
Traders said the market defied some pre-opening calls, which suggested prices would be supported throughout the day by bullish USDA weekly wheat export data.

"Early on, people thought we would rally because of the export sales number, so a lot of locals stocked up early. But then nothing happened. The locals got out fast and then we just leaked all day," an MGE floor source said.
Traders said most players expected Friday's report to show a sharp increase in USDA's estimates of total U.S. winter wheat production and overall world wheat carryout.

"Everybody's concerned about tomorrow's report, but there's some feeling that we've already priced a big number into the market and we could end up seeing a bounce if the number isn't all that big," a trader said.
A Reuters average of analysts' estimates put hard red winter wheat production at 1.000 billion bushels. That compares to USDA's June production estimate of 921 million bushels.
MGE spring wheat settled 4-3/4 cents a bushel higher in spot July, while other months fell four to nine cents. September dropped four cents to $3.55-1/4.
The MGE estimated Thursday's spring wheat futures volume at 19.62 million bushels, up from Wednesday's volume of 15.789 million bushels.
